items.title: Australian who escaped Iran says the protests — and the crackdown — are 'different this time'
items.description: On a visit to his home town outside Tehran, this Iranian Australian joined the protests last Thursday night, then the regime's suppression methods turned from tear gas to live fire.

items.title: Trump accepts Nobel medal from Machado 'for the work I have done'
items.description: The US president says he has accepted María Corina Machado's Nobel Peace Prize at a meeting in the White House, on account of "the work I have done".

items.title: Can Machado actually transfer the Nobel Peace Prize to Trump?
items.description: While it can be gifted, refused or displayed, the Nobel Peace Prize itself — once awarded — belongs to its original recipient forever.

items.title: Top faith leaders urge PM to scrap new racial hatred offence
items.description: A broad of coalition of Australia's most influential religious leaders have urged the prime minister to scrap Labor's proposal to outlaw the promotion of racial hatred.

items.title: Foreign fishing vessel filmed 100m away from Queensland coast
items.description: Locals on Queensland's far north tip have shared their account after seeing an Indonesian fishing boat within a stone's throw of the mainland.

items.title: What we know about the Great Ocean Road's unprecedented weather event
items.description: Record-breaking rain fell on the popular holiday towns in the space of a mere few hours on Thursday, triggering flash flooding that swept away cars, caravans and tents. Here's what we know about the intense rain system.

items.title: Tim Picton's alleged attacker accused of another assault, posting it on Snapchat
items.description: The man accused of assaulting former Labor strategist Tim Picton allegedly knocked another man unconscious two days prior.

items.title: Jim Chalmers defends Fed boss Jerome Powell as Trump attacks
items.description: Treasurer Jim Chalmers defends US central bank boss Jerome Powell as professional and diligent after the Trump administration launched a criminal investigation into the Federal Reserve chair.

items.title: Once top secret, Greenland's only US military base stirs trouble
items.description: Here is what we know about the US military footprint in Greenland, and how the increase of troops from Denmark and its allies stacks up.

items.title: Former South Korean president sentenced to jail over martial law declaration
items.description: Former South Korean president Yoon Suk Yeol is sentenced to five years in jail over crimes relating to his failed attempt at imposing martial law in the country.

items.title: Japan wants to mine the seabed at a depth of 6 kilometres for one reason: China
items.description: Tokyo hopes the plan to mine as much as 16 million tonnes of rare earths will help reduce its reliance on China, but will it work?

items.title: US lawsuit results in mystery cheque from Amazon in woman's mailbox
items.description: Australian woman Laura Wells was confused to find an "official-looking letter" from the US with a $51 reimbursement, but it turns out it was legitimate.

items.title: Melbourne sinkhole caused by test that 'should not have taken place'
items.description: The state's road building authority says a planned test should have been aborted given the circumstances, as tunnelling recommences for the North-East Link tunnel project.

items.title: Worker 'seriously injured' by falling excavator bucket at Darwin building site
items.description: A Darwin construction worker has been "seriously injured" after an excavator bucket fell and hit him, with paramedics transporting the man to hospital.

items.title: Engaged Aussie tennis stars qualify for Open within an hour of each other
items.description: Maddison Inglis and Jason Kubler were able to celebrate their Australian Open qualifications together in a heartwarming moment.

items.title: Police arrest 15, seize 12 firearms following Hobart shootings
items.description: Tasmania Police says it received "valuable information" from the public in relation to recent shootings in Gagebrook and Bridgewater.

items.title: How young people are finding ways to connect for free
items.description: How these young people are using sunrises and sunsets to create connection, build friendships and fight the war against loneliness.

items.title: Teen survives 80m mountain fall thanks to GPS locator and headphones
items.description: Jake McCollum's bluetooth headphones allowed him to receive calls through his otherwise unusable phone during the arduous wait for emergency services.

items.title: Heavy social media use and avoidance both linked to poorer wellbeing in teens
items.description: The findings of a newly released study have challenged one-size-fits-all rules and blanket bans, as the Australian government's social media ban for children under 16 has been in effect for over a month.

items.title: Pieced-together satellite images show bushfire crisis unfolding
items.description: Hundreds of images captured by an orbiting weather satellite, and stitched together by the ABC, show the scale and destructive force of the Victorian bushfires.

items.title: Missing man's body found at Darwin's East Point after large-scale search
items.description: NT police say they have recovered the body of a missing 44-year-old man, following a large-scale search-and-rescue operation in a Darwin reserve.

items.title: 'We have no knowledge of David': Fraudster registered as lobbyist for company
items.description: David Prince-Popovich registered as an official lobbyist in Tasmania despite being a convicted fraudster, against the register's rules.

items.title: Woman whose daughter died of drug overdose calls for changes to SA law
items.description: The mother of a woman who died of "mixed drug toxicity" is pushing for South Australia to implement penalties for those who do not call emergency services in a medical emergency.

items.title: Outrage after 'attack' on 100-year-old Anzac statue caught on CCTV
items.description: Residents of a north-west NSW town are angry and heartbroken after a statue with more than 100 years of history was unceremoniously shattered in the middle of the night.

items.title: Two blokes, whisky and lollies on a 'foolhardy' Bass Strait crossing
items.description: With whisky and lollies for sustenance and pigeons their only means of communication, Steve Harris and Doug Fleming crossed Bass Strait in a 4.5m dinghy in 1974.
